reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s stipulation v(extinction)=0 together with v(best feasible)=1, arguing this isn’t mere normalization but builds in that extinction is worse than the best feasible future and so excludes “pro‑extinction”/anti-natalist/etc. views. This is moderately central because the paper uses extinction as the zero point for its quantitative thresholds (mostly-great/eutopia) and for some comparisons, so excluding views where extinction is better than any survivable future narrows the scope. However, much of the paper’s ‘no easy eutopia’ case is conditional on survival and on frameworks where survival isn’t intrinsically good/bad in the extreme, so the critique doesn’t collapse the main argument—rather it trims its domain and challenges some rhetoric about neutrality. The critique is partly correct: setting extinction=0 alone could be an affine choice, but fixing both extinction=0 and best-feasible=1 does assume best-feasible > extinction, so it does exclude theories ranking extinction above all feasible survivals. Still, it overreaches by implying the stipulation automatically makes extinction better than all negative futures (that’s definitional given the scale, not an extra claim) and by asserting, without support, that the excluded views are “precisely” or “most plausibly” the easygoing alternatives. It is clear, focused, and contains little dead weight.
title: The zero-value extinction stipulation excludes the most plausible easygoing views
